## 3.2. SS Organization - Circuit Level

::::: columns

::: {.column width="65%"}
- Two sensory pathways to the CNS:
- Dorsal column-medial  lemniscal  tract (DCML)
    - High degree of spatial localization
    - Vibration, fine touch, proprioception
    - FAST: 30-110 m/sec
- Spinothalamic tract
    - Poor spatial localization
    - Temperature, crude touch, pressure, “pain”
    - SLOWER: 2-40 m/sec
- Both relay through the thalamus, terminate at the somatosensory cortex
:::

::: {.column width="35%"}
![](images/320.png){width=100%}
:::
:::::

{{< include ../notes/320.md >}}

## 3.3. SS Organization - Perceptual Level

::::: columns

::: {.column width="50%"}
- Receives input from all spinal cord ascending pathways
- Relays information to other parts of the brain dedicated to interpreting sensation (Parietal cortex)
- Spatially organized
- Larger area dedicated to region = more sensitivity
:::

## 4.1. Proprioception – Muscle Spindle

::::: columns

::: {.column width="50%"}
- Muscle spindle: Increased firing rate when muscle stretches ( Ia  afferent)
- Muscle spindle fires at a constant rate when relaxed
- Action potentials from gamma motor neurons cause contraction of  intrafusal  muscle fiber
- Stretch of  intrafusal  muscle fiber > increased firing rate from muscle spindle
- Relaxation > decreased firing rate
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
![](images/410.png){width=100%}
:::

## 4.4. Proprioception – Tactile Receptors

::::: columns

::: {.column width="50%"}
- Free nerve endings
    - Mechanoreceptive or  thermoreceptive
    - Stimulated by tissue damage (physical or temperature)
    - Detects ‘pain’, temperature, and crude touch
- Meissner’s corpuscle
    - Mechnoreceptive
    - Discharges at a low frequency (30-50 Hz)
    - Detects ‘flutter’, or light touch
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
![](images/440.png){width=100%}
:::

## 4.5. Proprioception – Corpuscles

::::: columns

::: {.column width="50%"}           
- Pacinian corpuscle
    - Mechanoreceptive
    - Discharges at a relatively high frequency (100-300 Hz)
    - Detects vibration
- Ruffini’s corpuscle
    - Mechanoreceptive, parallel to the surface of the skin
    - Collagen fibers inside lengthen when the skin does
    - Detects skin stretch
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
![](images/450.png){width=100%}

## 4.6. Proprioception – Merkel’s Disc

::::: columns

::: {.column width="60%"}
- Merkel’s disc
    - Mechanoreceptive
    - Distorts due to the skin above it moving
    - Detects fine touch and localization
- Hair follicle
    - Located at the base of individual hairs
    - Discharges when hair is displaced
    - Detects direction and velocity through hair movement
:::

## 6.1 Vestibular System - Semicircular Canals

::::: columns

::: {.column width="50%"}   
- Semicircular canals
- Filled with fluid (endolymph)
- Endolymph moves opposite to the head rotation
- Movement of fluid detected by hair cells in the cupula
:::

## 6.2 Vestibular System – Mechanotransduction

::::: columns

::: {.column width="50%"}
- Hair cells
- Composed of many  stereocilia  and one  kinocilium

## 6.3 Vestibular System – Polarization 

::::: columns

::: {.column width="50%"}
- Stereocilia  towards  kinocilium  = depolarization of hair cell
- Sterocilia  away from  kinocilium  = hyperpolarization

## 6.4 Vestibular System – Head Motion

::::: columns

::: {.column width="50%"}   
- Head rotation means one hair cell depolarizes, and the other side hyperpolarizes
    - Head rotation = CCW
        - CW endolymph fluid movement
        - Left semicircular canal:  stereocilia  pushed towards  kinocilium  (depolarization, excitation)
        - Right semicircular canal:  stereocilia  pushed away from  kinocilium  (hyperpolarization, inhibition)
:::

![](images/640.png){width=100%}

## 6.5 Vestibular System - Otoliths

::::: columns

::: {.column width="60%"}
- Otoliths: calcium carbonate crystals ( otoconia ) embedded into gelatinous material
- Hair cells project into material from the other side, and are displaced when the head moves linearly
- Utricle: horizontal linear acceleration
- Saccule: vertical linear acceleration
:::

## 7. Key takeaways

- Proprioception is essential for movement and balance, operating without visual input. Muscle spindles and Golgi tendon organs regulate muscle activity and prevent injury.
- Cutaneous receptors provide detailed sensations of touch, pressure, and temperature.
- The vestibular system, including the semicircular canals and otolith organs, is fundamental for equilibrium and spatial orientation.
- Hair cells transduce mechanical stimuli from movement and gravity into neural signals.
- The body’s sensory systems work in concert to create a comprehensive understanding of our environment and our place within it.
